title: Hennessy Round-robin Tournament
text:
The Hennessy Round-robin Tournament was a 12-man <a href="round-robin%20tournament">round-robin</a> <a href="golf">golf</a> tournament on the British PGA circuit contested in 1964. It was one of two round-robin events during the season, the <a href="Esso%20Golden%20Tournament">Esso Golden Tournament</a> being the other.
In essence, the Hennessy Round-robin was merely a change in format for the <a href="Hennessy%20Tournament">Hennessy Tournament</a>, a 72-hole <a href="stroke%20play">stroke play</a> tournament which ran from 1957 to 1965. It was played at the Clandeboye Golf Club near <a href="Bangor%2C%20County%20Down">Bangor</a>, <a href="County%20Down">County Down</a>, Northern Ireland, which had been the venue for the Hennessy Tournament since 1962. Total prize money was £1,500.
The tournament involved teams of three from each of the <a href="home%20nations">home nations</a>, with every player completing eleven 18-hole <a href="match%20play">matches</a> with points awarded for matches won or halved. <a href="Harry%20Weetman">Harry Weetman</a> won the individual event and alongside <a href="Peter%20Alliss">Peter Alliss</a> and <a href="Bernard%20Hunt">Bernard Hunt</a>, his England team won the team prize.
Tournament summary.
There were 12 competitors in 4 teams. The Republic of Ireland team was <a href="Christy%20Greene">Christy Greene</a>, <a href="Nicky%20Lynch">Nicky Lynch</a> and <a href="Christy%20O%27Connor%20Snr">Christy O'Connor Snr</a>. The Northern Ireland team was <a href="Jimmy%20Henderson%20%28golfer%29">Jimmy Henderson</a>, <a href="Hugh%20Jackson%20%28golfer%29">Hugh Jackson</a> and <a href="Ernie%20Jones%20%28golfer%29">Ernie Jones</a>. The England team was <a href="Peter%20Alliss">Peter Alliss</a>, <a href="Bernard%20Hunt">Bernard Hunt</a> and <a href="Harry%20Weetman">Harry Weetman</a>. The Scottish team was <a href="Eric%20Brown%20%28golfer%29">Eric Brown</a>, <a href="John%20Panton">John Panton</a> and <a href="George%20Will%20%28golfer%29">George Will</a>.
The competitors played each of the other 11 in an 18-hole <a href="match%20play">match play</a> contest. There were two points for a win and one for a halved match. Most matches were played as three-balls with each playing the other two simultaneously. The tournament was played over four days, from 26 to 29 May. Only the six Irish players competed on the first day, playing a singles match. They then played 5 rounds over the next three days. The English and Scottish competitors played 6 rounds on the remaining three days but in one of those matches they only played a single opponent.
<a href="Harry%20Weetman">Harry Weetman</a> won 9 of his 11 matches and halved another, giving him 19 points, 4 ahead of the rest. He had scored 17 points before the final afternoon round, 6 ahead of anyone else, giving him a guaranteed victory at that point since only 4 points were available in the final round. England won the team event with 44 points, ahead of Scotland with 37. Weetman won just over £400 for his individual and team successes.
